review.title: On Action Theory Change
review.abstract: As historically acknowledged in the Reasoning about Actions and Change community, intuitiveness of a logical domain description cannot be fully automated. Moreover, like any other logical theory, action theories may also evolve, and thus knowledge engineers need revision methods to help in accommodating new incoming information about the behavior of actions in an adequate manner. The present work is about changing action domain descriptions in multimodal logic. Its contribution is threefold: first we revisit the semantics of action theory contraction proposed in previous work, giving more robust operators that express minimal change based on a notion of distance between Kripke-models. Second we give algorithms for syntactical action theory contraction and establish their correctness with respect to our semantics for those action theories that satisfy a principle of modularity investigated in previous work. Since modularity can be ensured for every action theory and, as we show here, needs to be computed at most once during the evolution of a domain description, it does not represent a limitation at all to the method here studied. Finally we state AGM-like postulates for action theory contraction and assess the behavior of our operators with respect to them. Moreover, we also address the revision counterpart of action theory change, showing that it benefits from our semantics for contraction.

sections.heading: 5. Syntactic Operators for Contraction of Laws
sections.text: Once we have given a semantic construction for changing the theory of action, we now turn our attention to the definition of syntactic operators in order to change formulas that describe a dynamic range. As Nebel (1989) says, "[...] finite operators normally represent [...] laws, and when we are forced to change the theory, we want to stay as close as possible to the original [...] basis." Therefore, in addition to defining syntactic operators, we should also guarantee that they make minimal changes at the theoretical level. By this, we mean that the resulting theory should of course not include the law with which we want to contract the theory, and it should also retain as much foreknowledge as possible when making syntactical manipulations to the laws of the original theory. Ideally, from the point of view of the knowledge engineer, the modified theory should also have a certain degree of similarity with the original: the resulting laws should include minor modifications of the relevant laws in the original theory of action.

sections.heading: 6. Correctness of the Operators
sections.text: We are now dealing with the correctness of our algorithms in relation to our semantics of contraction. Correctness is understood here as completeness and appropriateness. Appropriateness means that the algorithms output only theories whose models result from our semantic modifications of models of the original theory. Conversely, completeness means that any model resulting from the semantic modifications of models of the original theory is actually a model of any theoretical output by the algorithm.

sections.heading: 6.3 Correctness Under Modularity
sections.text: As Herzig and Varzinczak (2007) have shown, it is always possible to guarantee modularity in the face of an action theory formalized with every framework available in the literature. Moreover, as we will see below (see Section 7.2), it must be calculated at most once during the evolution of action theory. Consequently, relying on modular theories is not a limitation at all in our approach. The following theorem states that, assuming that action theory T is modular, the semantic contraction of a formula from the series of models of T produces models of a contracted theory in T.

sections.text: Before answering this question, we should ask ourselves: Do our operators behave like revision or update operators? We will address this problem here and then show which postulates for theory changes are fulfilled by our definitions.

sections.heading: 7.1 Contraction or Erasure?
sections.text: The distinction between revision / contraction and actualization / deletion of classical theories is historically controversial in the literature. The same is true for modal theories that describe actions and their effects. We are here reformulating the definitions of Katsuno and Mendelzon (1992) in our terms so that we can see which of our methods are obvious. In Katsuno and Mendelzon's view, the contraction of a law from an action theory T intuitively means that the description of the possible behavior of dynamic world T must be adapted to the possibility of being incorrect. This amounts to selecting from the models of euro those that come closest to models of euro and allowing them as models of the result. sections.heading: 10. Concluding Remarks
sections.text: In this work, we have addressed the problem of changing a domain of action to argue about actions, a problem that has not been sufficiently investigated in the literature so far. We have seen the intuitions behind such a type of theory modification, and we have shown a semantics for changing the theory of action in relation to the distances between models that capture the notion of minimal change. We have also used algorithms to contract a formula that is correct in relation to our semantics (Corollars 6.1), we have shown the importance of broadening our concepts of modularity in other areas, we have also broadened Varzinczak's investigations by defining a semantics for the revision of action theory.

We here rephrase Katsuno and Mendelzon’s definitions (1992) in our terms so that we can see to which one our method is closer. In Katsuno and Mendelzon’s view, contracting a law Φ from an action theory T intuitively means that the description of the possible behavior of the dynamic world T must be adjusted to the possibility of Φ being false. This amounts to selecting from the models of ¬Φ those that are closest to models of T and allow them as models of the result. In contrast, update methods select, for each model M of T, the set of models of Φ that are closest to M . Erasing Φ from T means adding models to T; for each model M , we add all those models closest to M in which Φ is false. Hence, from our constructions so far it seems that our operators are closer to update than to revision. In their setting, during an update an action theory T is seen as composed of two pieces, Tu and Tm, where Tu stands for the part of T that is not supposed to change and Tm contains the laws which may be modified. In our terms, when contracting a static law we would have Tm = S ∪ Xa; when contracting an executability law Tm = Xa; and when contracting effects laws Tm = E− a . The difference here is that in our approach it is always clear what laws should not change in a given type of contraction, and therefore Tu and Tm do not need to be explicitly specified prior to the update. Their approach and ours can both be described as constraint-based update, in that the theory change is carried out relative to some constraints (a set of laws that we want to hold in the result). metadata.abstractText: As historically acknowledged in the Reasoning about Actions and Change community, intuitiveness of a logical domain description cannot be fully automated. Moreover, like any other logical theory, action theories may also evolve, and thus knowledge engineers need revision methods to help in accommodating new incoming information about the behavior of actions in an adequate manner. The present work is about changing action domain descriptions in multimodal logic. Its contribution is threefold: first we revisit the semantics of action theory contraction proposed in previous work, giving more robust operators that express minimal change based on a notion of distance between Kripke-models. Second we give algorithms for syntactical action theory contraction and establish their correctness with respect to our semantics for those action theories that satisfy a principle of modularity investigated in previous work. Since modularity can be ensured for every action theory and, as we show here, needs to be computed at most once during the evolution of a domain description, it does not represent a limitation at all to the method here studied. Finally we state AGM-like postulates for action theory contraction and assess the behavior of our operators with respect to them. Moreover, we also address the revision counterpart of action theory change, showing that it benefits from our semantics for contraction.
